3.text: G'day, my name is Josh Jensen. I'm a marine biologist and the underwater cameraman

10.text: I filmed the "Nature's Aquarium" series, and I'm going to talk you through some of what's

13.text: going on in the underwater scenes of this film. "Oceans" is basically a collection

18.text: of some of our favourite seascapes from the countries we visited and filmed over the past five years.

24.text: I think it's a privilege to be able to dive

26.text: and see what's under that big blue blanket, and I think that privilege

30.text: gives all divers an obligation to document that beauty to share with others if we can.

34.text: Our oceans are in serious trouble, and it's only through an awareness

40.text: that we can learn to use marine resources sustainably.

49.text: You can probably see that the current is running pretty hard in this shot:

52.text: the red sea whips are bent over, the fish are swimming pretty hard but not really going anywhere.

56.text: Current can be challenging, but it brings rewards.

59.text: In fact, pretty much the whole coral reef system—and in fact the entire marine world—

64.text: relies on currents, and specifically the plankton that the current brings with it.

68.text: Plankton is any organism that gets moved around more by the current

72.text: than by its own propulsion. There are literally millions

75.text: of tiny planktonic organisms flowing through this scene every second.

79.text: All those particles you can see, and even more way too small to see.

83.text: Plankton is what turns the water from crystal clear

87.text: into the maybe 30m/100ft visibility that you can see in this shot.

92.text: Some plankton are tiny things, smaller than bacteria, that get filtered by sponges;

97.text: next up in size are the single-celled plants called phytoplankton,

101.text: which might get filtered or eaten by microscopic animals called  zooplankton;

106.text: and all those zooplankton are eaten by small fish, which are eaten by the bigger fish.

111.text: Think of coral reefs as massive filters.

114.text: I'll often talk about plankton predators called planktivores.

118.text: Throughout the film, I'll also refer to a lot of critters as filter feeders,

121.text: and it is plankton that they are filtering and feeding on.

129.text: This is a typical remote Indonesian coral reef.

134.text: The school of small orange fish are one of the most common and conspicuous species of planktivores you'll find.

140.text: They're called Scalefin anthias, and these are all females.

145.text: For every 20 or so orange females, you'll see a mostly purple male,

151.text: and the male usually swims just above his harem, every now and then you'll see them

155.text: make frantic runs up and down as a display to the females and to rival males.

171.text: Each hard coral is actually a colony of hundreds to millions of tiny animals called polyps.

178.text: They're called reef building corals because their stony skeleton

181.text: creates habitat for the incredible diversity of reef fish.

186.text: Each fish has evolved to fill a specific niche created by the diverse coral growth forms.

194.text: and there are at least six different species in there—

198.text: they shelter amongst this staghorn coral during the day...

201.text: and at night they'll move up into the water column to feed,

204.text: and the daytime planktivores will move down into the staghorn coral to sleep.

216.text: Most species canʼt survive alone. This anemone, for example,

219.text: is in a mutualistic symbiotic relationship with clownfish—

222.text: that means both species benefit from the partnership.

225.text: The clownish defends the anemone from butterflyfish attack,

229.text: and the clownfish get a safe place to live and lay their eggs.

232.text: Itʼs a really well-studied and well-understood field...

235.text: but there are strange things going on in this shot:

240.text: thatʼs the single grey fish here—they arenʼt normally associated with anemones,

244.text: but this guy is most likely waiting to be cleaned. There are usually cleaner shrimp on anemones,

249.text: but itʼs probably the juvenile Blunthead wrasse—those are the black and white ones—

253.text: or the juvenile cleaner wrasse that will dance in shortly—

256.text: that will do the cleaning in this particular station.

259.text: Whatʼs extra unusual about this shot is the Sixstripe wrasse—the little pink and green fish swimming throughout the tentacles—

265.text: heʼs not supposed to be able to do that without getting stung and eaten.

274.text: There are hundreds of species of animals that we never see—

277.text: mostly worms, but also crustaceans and molluscs—that live

284.text: If you were to slice down into that coral rock youʼd find it looks like Swiss cheese: lots of holes in it.

289.text: The big fella feeding here is a Titan triggerfish

292.text: and he is biting off chunks of that rock with incredibly strong teeth and

296.text: powerful jaws to find big juicy worms that he knows live inside.

302.text: But in searching for those big worms, he is also exposing lots of smaller worms and other critters,

306.text: and thatʼs food for all the other fish species you can see here.

310.text: Thereʼs a Moorish idol, a pair of Pacific double-saddled butterflyfish,

314.text: a Checkerboard wrasse... there will also be smaller wrasse and hawkfish hanging around looking for scraps, too.

319.text: Titan triggerfish almost always have an entourage of these

323.text: opportunists which are attracted to the scene by the crunching sound of coral being broken.
